primary_laws.name: Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)
primary_laws.description: Federal law establishing minimum wage, overtime pay, recordkeeping, and child labor standards

primary_laws.name: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act
primary_laws.description: Prohibits employment discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, and national origin

primary_laws.name: Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)
primary_laws.description: Prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities

at_will.description: Default employment relationship in most US states where either party can terminate at any time, with or without cause
at_will.employee_risk: Can be terminated without notice or severance
at_will.recommendation: Negotiate notice period or severance terms if possible

nonexempt.description: Employees entitled to minimum wage and overtime pay

exempt.description: Employees not entitled to overtime (must meet specific criteria)
exempt.warning: Misclassification is a major compliance risk

minimum_wage.note: Many states and cities have higher minimums
minimum_wage.compliance_rule: Must pay the higher of federal, state, or local minimum

state_variations.california: Daily overtime after 8 hours; double time after 12 hours

required_records: Employee full name and Social Security number
Time and day of week when workweek begins
Hours worked each day and total hours each workweek
Total daily or weekly straight-time earnings
Total overtime earnings for the workweek
All additions to or deductions from wages
Total wages paid each pay period
Date of payment and pay period covered
recordkeeping.retention_period: 3 years for payroll records; 2 years for time cards

should_include.note: Defines scope of work; can limit duty expansion
Expected hours; basis for overtime calculation

legally_required.requirement: Most states require notice of workers' comp coverage
Recommended for compliance with anti-discrimination laws

risk_patterns.name: Employee Misclassification
risk_patterns.description: Treating employees as independent contractors or exempt when they don't qualify
risk_patterns.legal_test: Economic reality test (DOL) / ABC test (many states)
risk_patterns.penalties: Back wages, overtime, benefits, penalties, legal fees
indicators: Exempt classification without meeting duties test

risk_patterns.name: At-Will Without Protections
risk_patterns.description: Contract allows termination without any notice period
risk_patterns.standard_practice: Most US contracts include at-will language
risk_patterns.employee_risk: Immediate job loss with no warning
risk_patterns.recommendation: Negotiate 2-week notice period or severance if key employee

risk_patterns.name: Overtime Waiver Attempt
risk_patterns.description: Contract attempts to waive overtime rights for non-exempt employees
risk_patterns.legal_status: FLSA overtime rights cannot be waived by contract
red_flags: Comp time instead of overtime pay (private sector)

risk_patterns.name: Overly Broad Non-Compete

state_variations.new_york: Must be reasonable in time, geography, scope
state_variations.texas: Enforceable if ancillary to enforceable agreement

risk_patterns.ftc_rule_2024: FTC proposed banning most non-competes (pending litigation)
risk_patterns.recommendation: Check state law; limit to 1-2 years and specific geography

risk_patterns.name: Mandatory Arbitration Clause
risk_patterns.description: Requires employee to waive right to court/jury trial
risk_patterns.employee_impact: Limits legal remedies; often favors employers

risk_patterns.name: Broad IP Assignment / Work for Hire
risk_patterns.description: Assigns all work product including personal projects
risk_patterns.recommendation: Ensure personal projects outside work hours are excluded

key_differences: Limited state employment protections beyond federal

employer_must_provide: Written notice of pay rate (many states)

sources: Cornell Law School Legal Information Institute
